I have yet to read that paper (thanks for the link), but for now everything=
 (not much) I found seems to treat some kind of "Asynchronous REST&quo=
t; as a extension of the simple request/response scheme, by allowing some k=
ind of "deferred" response, or "notifications".<br /><b=
r />I was thinking more in terms of push technology, in which a request can=
 be started by the server instead of the client. What does that to our cons=
traints?<br /><br />Client/server model -> breaks (in the sense that cli=
ent/server being equivalent to request/response)<br />Stateless protocols -=
> breaks? probably not<br />Caching -> breaks?<br />Uniform Interface=
 -> doesn't necessarily break, but it could<br />Layering -> does=
n't necessarily break<br />Optional Code-on-demand -> definitely doe=
sn't break<br /><br />Identification of resources -> doesn't bre=
ak<br />Manipulation of resources through representations  -> doesn'=
t break, although the term "manipulation" here may not be the bes=
t <br />Self-descriptive messages  -> doesn't break ?<br />Hypermedi=
a as the engine of application state. -> it could break, and it probably=
 will break<br /><br /><br />However, if it break some of the constraints y=
ou can't call it REST, so basically the question will be: can REST be t=
he architecture style of a Asynchronous Web application, or do we need a &q=
uot;revised" REST" or even a complete new style?<br /><br /><br /=
